raw_text:
Wilkinson to miss Ireland match
 
 England will have to take on Ireland in the Six Nations without captain and goal-kicker Jonny Wilkinson, according to his Newcastle boss Rob Andrew.
 
 Wilkinson - who had targeted the 27 February match for his international comeback - has been missed by England, not least for his goal-kicking. "Jonny's not fit yet," Falcons chief Andrew told BBC Radio Five Live. "He won't be fit for Dublin, there's no doubt about that, but he might be fit for Scotland and Italy." The 25-year-old has not played for England since the 2003 World Cup final after a succession of injuries. England, who have lost three Six Nations games in a row, wasted a 17-6 half-time lead in their 18-17 defeat to France. Goal-kickers Charlie Hodgson and Olly Barkley missed six penalty attempts and a drop-goal between them. "They've probably got two of the best English kickers in the Premiership in Hodgson and Barkley," added Andrew, a former England fly-half and goal-kicker.
 
 "They're both pretty good kickers. Charlie is a good kicker week-in, week-out. "But it's all about pressure and unfortunately England are just not handling the pressure at the moment." Andrew also blamed England's poor run of recent results on a lack of leadership in the side following several high-profile retirements and injuries. "They just didn't have that leadership that would have seen them through. Martin Johnson, Lawrence Dallaglio and Jonny are obviously huge losses and leadership is so important in those situations," he said. "I think it is really difficult for Jason Robinson to lead the side effectively from full-back." Meanwhile, former England full-back Dusty Hare put England's mistakes down to a lack of mental toughness.
 
 "Jonny Wilkinson has proved himself a cool customer with around an 80% kicking success rate," Hare told BBC Radio Five Live. "But natural-born toughness comes into it as well as all the practice you do. "You have to be able to shut out all the outside elements and concentrate on putting the ball between the posts." Hodgson, who has an excellent kicking record with club side Sale Sharks, has introduced crowd noise into his practice routine of late. "The top golfers don't hit the fairway every time, and it is the same with goal-kicking," Hare added. "You need that mental toughness as well to put the ball over, but great goal-kickers like Jonny Wilkinson come along very rarely."
llama3.2:1b:
England will play Ireland without captain Jonny Wilkinson due to injury. 

Andrew has stated Wilkinson won't be fit for Dublin. 

Wilkinson's goal-kicking was affected by injury. 

The team's poor run of results is attributed to a lack of leadership.

Former England full-back Dusty Hare attributes mistakes to mental toughness.
llama3.2:3b: Wilkinson will miss Ireland match due to injury, leaving England without captain and goal-kicker for their next Six Nations game. The team's poor recent performance is partly attributed to a lack of leadership following high-profile retirements and injuries. Goal-kickers Charlie Hodgson and Olly Barkley struggled under pressure in the loss to France, with expert Dusty Hare blaming a lack of mental toughness and natural-born coolness as key factors.
gemma2:2b: England will play Ireland without captain Jonny Wilkinson due to injury.  England's goal-kicking has been a problem, with both Charlie Hodgson and Olly Barkley missing several attempts in their last game against France.  Former England players believe this is partly due to the absence of key leadership figures and that a lack of mental toughness contributes to England’s recent struggles.
qwen2.5:0.5b:
England will miss Jonny Wilkinson in their Six Nations match against Ireland. Wilkinson was targeted for the 27 February game, but he hasn't played since losing his spot at full-back following the 2003 World Cup final and not playing for England since then.

Former England full-back Dusty Hare points out that Jonny Wilkinson has a 80% kicking success rate. He says "great goal-kickers like Jonny Wilkinson come along very rarely" because they need to put the ball over, but he adds: "It is the same with kickers like Charlie Hodgson and Olly Barkley who are good kickers week-in-week-out."

Former England fly-half and goal kicker Jack Wilbraham also says that the best English kickers have a 80% kicking success rate. He points out that Charlie Hodgson and Olly Barkley have an excellent kicking record with Sale Sharks, but says: "You need mental toughness to put the ball over."

Andrew attributes their poor form to leadership gaps following retirements and injuries, particularly in the absence of Martin Johnson, Lawrence Dallaglio, and Jonny Wilkinson. Former full-back Dusty Hare suggests a lack of mental toughness is contributing to their struggles, emphasizing the importance of focus during goal-kicking routines.

The article also talks about England's kickers, Charlie Hodgson and Olly Barkley, who missed penalties. Hodgson has issues hitting the fairway because of crowd noise, which affects his goal-kicking.

Dusty Hare from BBC Radio Five Live breaks down the situation, highlighting Wilson's reliability with an 80% success rate in kickers. However, natural toughness is also crucial for effective goal-kicking, as seen with Hodgson and Barkley. Despite this, Wilson is frequently overlooked due to his limited performance in recent matches, where he has struggled to maintain his discipline against outside factors like crowd noise.

England lost three Six Nations matches in a row and has dropped down the rankings following a poor run of results.

granite3.1-dense:2b:
England's captain and goal-kicker, Jonny Wilkinson, will not participate in their upcoming match against Ireland on February 27 due to an injury. This news comes from Newcastle boss Rob Andrew, who stated that Wilkinson is not fit for the game but may recover for matches against Scotland and Italy. Wilkinson's absence impacts England's performance, as they have struggled with recent losses in the Six Nations tournament. The team missed crucial penalty attempts during their 18-17 defeat to France, with Charlie Hodgson and Olly Barkley both failing to convert multiple kicking opportunities.

Andrew attributes England's poor form partly to a lack of leadership following the retirements or injuries of notable players like Martin Johnson, Lawrence Dallaglio, and Jonny Wilkinson. He notes that effective leadership is essential for guiding the team through challenging situations. Former England full-back Dusty Hare also emphasizes the importance of mental toughness in goal-kicking, comparing it to golf. Hare highlights Jonny Wilkinson's exceptional kicking ability and natural toughness as key factors in his success.

Hodgson, who has demonstrated strong club form with Sale Sharks, is incorporating crowd noise into his practice routines to improve his mental resilience for high-pressure situations. Overall, England faces significant challenges due to the absence of their experienced captain and goal-kicker, as well as a potential lack of leadership and mental fortitude within the team.
